It sounds like you're referring to the hadith about the qualities of **forbearance (ḥilm)** and **deliberation (anāh)** that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) praised in a companion. 

The hadith is narrated in **Sahih Muslim**:

> **“You have two qualities that Allah loves: forbearance (ḥilm) and deliberation (anāh).”**  
> (Sahih Muslim 17:25)

This was said to **Ashajj ‘Abd al-Qays**, a leader of the tribe of **‘Abd al-Qays**, when he came to visit the Prophet ﷺ. Unlike others in his delegation who rushed to meet the Prophet, Ashajj took his time, changing his clothes and preparing himself properly before approaching. The Prophet ﷺ recognized this as a sign of wisdom and praised his calm, deliberate nature.

This hadith emphasizes the value of being composed, patient, and thoughtful in one’s actions. It suggests that these qualities are not just personal virtues but are beloved by Allah.
In Arabic and English in full please

Certainly! Here is the full hadith in Arabic along with its English translation:

### **Hadith in Arabic**  
عَنْ ابْنِ عَبَّاسٍ، قَالَ قَالَ رَسُولُ اللَّهِ ﷺ لِأَشَجِّ عَبْدِ الْقَيْسِ ‏ **"إِنَّ فِيكَ خَصْلَتَيْنِ يُحِبُّهُمَا اللَّهُ الْحِلْمُ وَالْأَنَاةُ"**‏  

*(صحيح مسلم 17:25)*  

### **English Translation**  
Ibn Abbas (may Allah be pleased with him) reported that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said to **Ashajj ‘Abd al-Qays**:  

**"Indeed, you have two qualities that Allah loves: forbearance (ḥilm) and deliberation (anāh)."**  

*(Sahih Muslim 17:25)*  

This hadith teaches the virtues of patience, thoughtfulness, and not acting in haste, qualities that are loved by Allah.
